articles.headline: In Shift, U.S. Says Marriage Act Blocks Gay Rights
articles.snippet: When suits challenge the 1996 law barring recognition of same-sex marriages, federal lawyers will now tell judges it should be struck down.
articles.abstract: When suits challenge the 1996 law barring recognition of same-sex marriages, federal lawyers will now tell judges it should be struck down.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, in a striking legal and political shift, has determined that the Defense of Marriage Act — the 1996 law that bars federal recognition of same-sex marriages — is unconstitutional, and has directed the Justice Department to stop defending the law in court, the administration said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Solar Energy Faces Tests On Greenness
articles.snippet: Five solar thermal projects in California are being challenged in court by labor, environmental and American Indian groups.
articles.abstract: Five solar thermal projects in California are being challenged in court by labor, environmental and American Indian groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Just weeks after regulators approved the last of nine multibillion-dollar solar thermal power plants to be built in the Southern California desert, a storm of lawsuits and the resurgence of an older solar technology are clouding the future of the nascent industry.

articles.headline: Why the Disruption of Libyan Oil Has Led to a Price Spike
articles.snippet: Libya produces less than 2 percent of the world’s oil, but its light sweet crude magnifies its importance.
articles.abstract: Libya produces less than 2 percent of the world’s oil, but its light sweet crude magnifies its importance.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Crude oil prices reached $100 a barrel in the United States on Wednesday, the highest price in more than two years, as Middle East oil flows were interrupted this week for the first time since the region’s turmoil began.

articles.headline: Airfares Are Chasing Oil Prices Higher
articles.snippet: Airlines have raised their fares four times since the start of the year, in contrast to only three increases for all of 2010.
articles.abstract: Airlines have raised their fares four times since the start of the year, in contrast to only three increases for all of 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airline passengers should prepare themselves for sticker shock this year.

articles.headline: Opposition Arises to Charities’ Merger
articles.snippet: According to some board members, the merger of Smile Train and Operation Smile was the culmination of a feud.
articles.abstract: According to some board members, the merger of Smile Train and Operation Smile was the culmination of a feud.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last decade, Smile Train and Operation Smile have been the Hatfields and McCoys of the charity world.

articles.headline: Arab Unrest Propels Iran as Saudi Influence Declines
articles.snippet: Iran has already benefited from the ouster or undermining of Arab leaders who were its strong adversaries and has begun to project its growing influence, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Iran has already benefited from the ouster or undermining of Arab leaders who were its strong adversaries and has begun to project its growing influence, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain  The popular revolts shaking the Arab world have begun to shift the balance of power in the region, bolstering Iran’s position while weakening and unnerving its rival, Saudi Arabia, regional experts said.

articles.headline: Before Rush, One Tablet Stands Out
articles.snippet: The Motorola Xoom, one of the most eagerly awaited iPad rivals, has arrived. It has slightly upgraded hardware, but its Google tablet software, known as Honeycomb, is the more important story.
articles.abstract: The Motorola Xoom, one of the most eagerly awaited iPad rivals, has arrived. It has slightly upgraded hardware, but its Google tablet software, known as Honeycomb, is the more important story.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s an old pattern by now. Phase 1: Apple introduces some new gadget. The bloggers and the industry tell us why it’ll fail. Phase 2: It goes on sale. The public goes nuts for it. Phase 3: Every company and its brother gets to work on a copycat.

articles.headline: Concerns for Boeing Grow as a Tanker Decision Nears
articles.snippet: Supporters of Boeing are questioning the fairness of the bidding, while EADS, its European rival, seems confident it will win the $35 billion contract.
articles.abstract: Supporters of Boeing are questioning the fairness of the bidding, while EADS, its European rival, seems confident it will win the $35 billion contract.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Air Force tries to end its long and often embarrassing effort to buy new aerial fueling tankers, Boeing’s supporters are questioning the fairness of the bidding, while its European rival seems confident it will win the $35 billion contract.

articles.headline: Life on the Run for Democrats in Union Fights
articles.snippet: Illinois has suddenly found itself the refuge of choice for lawmakers fleeing their states to block the bills.
articles.abstract: Illinois has suddenly found itself the refuge of choice for lawmakers fleeing their states to block the bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — By now, Jon Erpenbach, one of 14 Democratic state senators on the run from Wisconsin, has switched hotels in this city three times, a necessity, he says, as word kept slipping out about where he was staying.

articles.headline: Libyan Rebels Repel Qaddafi’s Forces Near Tripoli
articles.snippet: Protests evolved into a well-armed revolutionary movement as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi blamed drugging by Osama bin Laden for the violence.
articles.abstract: Protests evolved into a well-armed revolutionary movement as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi blamed drugging by Osama bin Laden for the violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya  Rebels seeking to overturn the 40-year rule of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi repelled a concerted assault by his forces on Thursday on cities close to the capital, removing any doubt that Libya’s patchwork of protests had evolved into an increasingly well-armed revolutionary movement.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Resurgent G.M. Posts 2010 Profit of $4.7 Billion
articles.snippet: General Motors said that it earned $4.7 billion in 2010 and that union workers would receive profit-sharing checks of $4,300, the most in the automaker’s history.
articles.abstract: General Motors said that it earned $4.7 billion in 2010 and that union workers would receive profit-sharing checks of $4,300, the most in the automaker’s history.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors, which nearly collapsed from the weight of its debts two years ago before reorganizing in a government-sponsored bankruptcy, said on Thursday that it earned $4.7 billion in 2010, the most in more than a decade.

articles.headline: Foreign Investment Ebbs in India
articles.snippet: Direct investment in India fell more than 31 percent last year, and corruption and bureaucracy are being blamed.
articles.abstract: Direct investment in India fell more than 31 percent last year, and corruption and bureaucracy are being blamed.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  India’s rise has captured the world’s imagination, as the economy grows at nearly 9 percent a year and a growing consumer class buys cellphones, cars and homes. Yet foreign businesses and investors, once increasingly eager to tap that stunning growth, have started looking elsewhere.
